content.text: Once upon a time, in a quiet little village nestled between rolling green hills, there lived a wealthy merchant and his kind wife.
They had everything their hearts desired—except for one thing.
They longed for a child, but no matter how much they wished, none came.
One winter’s evening, as the snow fell softly outside, the wife stood by the window, gazing at the juniper tree in their garden.
Its branches were heavy with snow, and its dark green needles shimmered in the moonlight.

“I wish,” she sighed, “that I had a child as red as blood and as white as snow.” And as she spoke, she pricked her finger on a needle from the tree, and three drops of blood fell onto the snow beneath the juniper.

The sight of the red blood on the white snow filled her heart with hope, and she whispered, “Oh, if only I had a child with skin as white as snow and cheeks as red as blood!”  Not long after, her wish came true.
She gave birth to a beautiful baby boy, with skin as white as snow and cheeks as red as blood.
The merchant and his wife were overjoyed, and they loved their son more than anything in the world.
But sadly, the wife grew very ill after the birth, and though she tried to be strong, she knew her time was near.
With her last breath, she made her husband promise two things: first, that he would always love and care for their son, and second, that he would bury her beneath the juniper tree when she passed.
The merchant wept bitterly, but he promised to do as she asked.
He buried his beloved wife beneath the juniper tree, and though his heart was heavy, he tried to be brave for his little boy.
Time passed, and the merchant’s grief began to fade.
One day, he met a woman who was kind and gentle, and before long, they were married.
She brought with her a daughter of her own, a girl named Marlinchen, who was sweet and good-natured.
At first, the stepmother loved the merchant’s son as if he were her own, but as time went on, her heart grew cold toward him.
She could not bear the way her husband doted on the boy, nor the way the villagers admired his beauty and kindness.
Jealousy took root in her heart, and she began to treat him cruelly.
One day, the stepmother was making applesauce in the kitchen.
The boy, who was hungry, came in and asked for an apple.
The stepmother had a basket of apples beside her—some ripe and red, others green and sour.
She reached into the basket and pulled out a bright red apple, but instead of giving it to the boy, she held it high above her head.
“Jump for it,” she said with a wicked smile.
“If you can reach it, you may have it.”  The boy, eager to please, jumped as high as he could.
But the stepmother was too quick.
She slammed the lid of the apple basket shut with all her might, crushing the boy’s head.
His little body fell to the floor, and the stepmother, trembling with fear, quickly hid what she had done.
She took the boy’s body and chopped it into pieces, then cooked him into a stew.
She served it to her husband that evening, telling him the boy had gone to visit relatives.
The merchant ate the stew without suspicion, for he trusted his wife.
But Marlinchen, who had seen everything, was filled with horror.
She could not bring herself to eat a single bite.
Instead, she gathered the bones from her plate and wrapped them in a silk handkerchief.
She carried them outside and buried them beneath the juniper tree, where her mother had been laid to rest.
From that day on, a strange and wondrous thing began to happen.
A beautiful bird with feathers as bright as gold and as red as fire appeared in the branches of the juniper tree.
The bird sang the most enchanting songs, and all who heard it were filled with joy.
One day, the bird flew to the village goldsmith and sang:  *“My mother she killed me, My father he ate me, My sister Marlinchen gathered my bones, And buried them ‘neath the juniper stones.
Tweet, tweet!
What a beautiful bird am I!”*  The goldsmith was so moved by the song that he gave the bird a golden chain in exchange for its beauty.
The bird then flew to the shoemaker and sang the same song.
The shoemaker, delighted, gave the bird a pair of red shoes.
Finally, the bird flew to the mill, where twenty millers’ boys were hard at work.
It perched on a branch and sang its song once more.
The millers’ boys were so charmed that they gave the bird a heavy millstone.
With its treasures in tow, the bird flew back to the merchant’s house.
It perched on the roof and began to sing its song again.
The merchant, hearing the beautiful melody, stepped outside to listen. The bird dropped the golden chain into his hands.
The stepmother, drawn by the music, came out as well, and the bird dropped the red shoes at her feet.
But Marlinchen, who had been watching from the window, ran outside with tears in her eyes.
The bird flew down and dropped the millstone onto the stepmother’s head, crushing her instantly.
At that very moment, a great wind swept through the garden, and the juniper tree shook violently.
When the wind died down, the little boy stood before them, alive and whole once more.
His father and Marlinchen rushed to embrace him, their hearts filled with joy.
And from that day forward, the merchant, his son, and Marlinchen lived together in happiness, never again to be parted by sorrow.
